meta.question: Read the smaller words to form a compound word.

meta.hint:
The prefix -pre means before.
The prefix -re means again.
The prefix -mis means incorrectly or poorly
meta.question: Determine the meaning of the word with the prefix.

blocks.name: Meaning of the word with -pre, -re, or -mis

meta.question: Identify the base word, prefix or suffix from the following.
meta.hint:
Base words are words that can be combined with prefixes and suffixes. They also can be used on their own.
Example - Unhelpful -> Base word is help, the prefix is -un, and the suffix is -ful.

blocks.name: Meaning of the word with -ful or -less.

meta.hint:
The prefix -pre means before.
The prefix -re means again.
The prefix -mis means incorrectly or poorly.
meta.question: Determine the meaning of the word with the prefix.

meta.hint:
A sentence is a group of words that forms a complete thought.
It has both a subject and a verb. Example - My friends walk along the path.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought. It is usually missing a subject or a verb.
Example - Knows the answer. This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a subject. Who knows the answer? She knows the answer.
Example -The bright red car. This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a verb. What did the bright red car do? The bright red car stopped.
A run-on sentence also called a run-together sentence , is made up of two sentences that should stand alone.
Example - I knocked on the door it opened.
To fix a run-on sentence, separate it into two sentences. Add a full stop after the first sentence, and use a capital letter at the beginning of the second sentence. Example - I knocked on the door. It opened.
meta.question: Is it a complete sentence,  a fragment or a run-on sentence?

blocks.name: A Complete sentence or a Sentence fragment or run-on sentence?

meta.question: Identify whether the given sentence is a statement, question, command or exclamation?
meta.hint:
A statement tells you about something. It ends with a full stop. eg. Tarun took a cookie.
A question asks something. It ends with a question mark. eg. Are you coming with me to the party?
An exclamation is like a statement but shows surprise or a strong feeling. It ends with an exclamation mark. eg. How beautiful this city is!
A command tells someone to do something. Most of the time, a command ends with a full stop. If it shows a strong feeling, it ends with an exclamation mark. eg. Open the door! Come with me.

A noun is a word that names a person, place, or thing.
A common noun names a general type of person, place, or thing. A common noun does not begin with a capital letter, except when it is the first word in a sentence.
A proper noun names a specific person, place, or thing. A proper noun always begins with a capital letter.
Common Nouns Proper Nouns Boy Jacob Day Tuesday Street Elm Street City Mumbai
meta.question: Identify whether the noun in bold  is a common or proper noun.

meta.hint:
A noun is a word that names a person, place or thing.
Some nouns name people, like woman, friend and teacher.
Some nouns name places, like town, library and park.
Some nouns name things, like bicycle, horse and flower.
meta.question: Is the word in bold a noun?
